intro: Neolitsea howii, commonly known as the Hawaiian hala tree, is a member of the Lauraceae family and is native to the Hawaiian Islands. It is a small to medium-sized evergreen tree that typically grows in coastal and lowland forests. The plant has simple, alternate leaves that are elliptical in shape and have a smooth, glossy surface. Its flowers are small and clustered, and it produces dark blue, fleshy berries that are edible. Neolitsea howii plays an important ecological role in its native habitat, providing food and shelter for various wildlife species.
